channel.title: RS ingame texture modifying
channel.description:
ok well i just stumbled apon somthing here, its rather cool.
what you can do is change the textures of rs whilst playing the game.
heres some pictures...
[img]http://i45.tinypic.com/r91s02.jpg[/img]
(invisible legs if you dont know what ur looking at)
[img]http://i45.tinypic.com/2wc3a7a.jpg[/img]
pasted textures on the ground :D
VID ON HOW TO
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H9eecmY60rU
the reason i posted this is maby somone here could use this to do somthing cool? i dont know, i just stumbled upon it one day.
(btw, you must have all the graphics on max to make this work(i think, well atleast have textures on))

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:15, topic:346538”]If anyone is interested: http://www.opengl.org/sdk/docs/man/

Will look tomorrow, in CS the objects were drawn using different modes, but I think RS will use polygons for it all, so I will have to try find a different way of hacking the openGL.[/quote]OpenGL is pretty simple shit, rs most likely uses vbo’s for all the polygon data, so you can just grab that.

Read full topic

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:346538”]Guys You’re Doing It Wrong:

Hardness 2/0

Open Class30_Sub2_Sub1_Sub3

And Find : public static final int[] method371(int i)

Under The : {
Add

[quote]if (i == 1) { i = 40; }

if (i == 2) { i = 40; }

if (i == 3) { i = 40; }

if (i == 4) { i = 40; }

if (i == 5) { i = 40; }

if (i == 6) { i = 40; }

if (i == 7) { i = 40; }

if (i == 8) { i = 40; }

if (i == 9) { i = 40; }

if (i == 10) { i = 40; }

if (i == 11) { i = 40; }

if (i == 12) { i = 40; }

if (i == 13) { i = 40; }

if (i == 14) { i = 40; }

if (i == 15) { i = 40; }

if (i == 16) { i = 40; }

if (i == 17) { i = 40; }

if (i == 18) { i = 40; }

if (i == 19) { i = 40; }

if (i == 20) { i = 40; }

if (i == 21) { i = 40; }

if (i == 22) { i = 40; }

if (i == 32) { i = 40; }

if (i == 33) { i = 40; }

if (i == 34) { i = 40; }

if (i == 35) { i = 40; }

if (i == 36) { i = 40; }

if (i == 37) { i = 40; }

if (i == 38) { i = 40; }

if (i == 39) { i = 40; }

if (i == 40) { i = 40; }

if (i == 41) { i = 40; }

if (i == 42) { i = 40; }

if (i == 43) { i = 40; }

if (i == 44) { i = 40; }

if (i == 45) { i = 40; }

if (i == 46) { i = 40; }

if (i == 47) { i = 40; }

if (i == 50) { i = 40; }[/quote]

Looks Like This : Pretty Cool

ontopic: It would be quite cool if someone utilized this by painting objects/npcs if different colors.[/quote]WHAT THE FUCK IS THAT SHIT?

if(i > 0 && i < 51) { i = 40; }

If anyone is interested: http://www.opengl.org/sdk/docs/man/

Will look tomorrow, in CS the objects were drawn using different modes, but I think RS will use polygons for it all, so I will have to try find a different way of hacking the openGL.

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:11, topic:346538”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=442918.msg3253349#msg3253349 date=1277933582]

Effectively that’s what it would be doing, but Speljohan we don’t want to colour EVERY model, as if there are 20 red monsters, different types, on the screen, how will I know which one to click?
[/quote]They all get a different brightness etc, and then you just have them mapped to id’s using a definition dump from cache, simple as that

I suppose you could, but then that would be hackery, I would prefer to be able to choose what models to colour, would look cooler too :D[/quote]Yeah, that’s true. When a script runs something, it would just color stuff in some random color automatically and find it, lol

Read full topic

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:10, topic:346538”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=442918.msg3253318#msg3253318 date=1277932691]
Effectively that’s what it would be doing, but Speljohan we don’t want to colour EVERY model, as if there are 20 red monsters, different types, on the screen, how will I know which one to click?
[/quote]They all get a different brightness etc, and then you just have them mapped to id’s using a definition dump from cache, simple as that :)[/quote]

I suppose you could, but then that would be hackery, I would prefer to be able to choose what models to colour, would look cooler too

Read full topic

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Effectively that’s what it would be doing, but Speljohan we don’t want to colour EVERY model, as if there are 20 red monsters, different types, on the screen, how will I know which one to click?

You don’t, which is why the OpenGL/DirectX would need to be modified so that it can talk to your client. I think the injecting approach is getting slightly dated, it’s been around for a while.

Not many people are coming up with new ideas. Maybe people have got lazy, or maybe people are just not smart enough any more! I might have to try something soon to see if I can spark an interest again, I need to earn a few $$ from farming a few accounts anyway

Read full topic

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:5, topic:346538”]Heh, would be nice if you could choose what textures were drawn where, just like when I made a CS aimbot I converted the head models to either bright cyan or bright magenta depending on the team and got the application to move mouse to that spot, obviously a retarded way to do it but I was young and stupid ^^.

Same concept could be used here, highlight monsters certain colours, I.e. target monster (use some reflection) colour bright red, use a colour finder to grab the midpoint and go and click. Same could be done for all objects.

Will have a look into it, but I have never really played with DirectX, has anyone got any documentation on it?[/quote]Why not just write an algorithm to color an npc/object/item etc by their id? That way you can make it pretty simple.

Read full topic

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:5, topic:346538”]Heh, would be nice if you could choose what textures were drawn where, just like when I made a CS aimbot I converted the head models to either bright cyan or bright magenta depending on the team and got the application to move mouse to that spot, obviously a retarded way to do it but I was young and stupid ^^.

Same concept could be used here, highlight monsters certain colours, I.e. target monster (use some reflection) colour bright red, use a colour finder to grab the midpoint and go and click. Same could be done for all objects.

Will have a look into it, but I have never really played with DirectX, has anyone got any documentation on it?[/quote]

You could probably use OpenGL much easier to accomplish the same thing.

Read full topic

item.title: RS ingame texture modifying
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Heh, would be nice if you could choose what textures were drawn where, just like when I made a CS aimbot I converted the head models to either bright cyan or bright magenta depending on the team and got the application to move mouse to that spot, obviously a retarded way to do it but I was young and stupid ^^.

Same concept could be used here, highlight monsters certain colours, I.e. target monster (use some reflection) colour bright red, use a colour finder to grab the midpoint and go and click. Same could be done for all objects.

Will have a look into it, but I have never really played with DirectX, has anyone got any documentation on it?

Read full topic
